titleStmt.title: Multiple-Attribute Decision-Making based on Archimedean Bonferroni Operators of q-Rung Orthopair Fuzzy Numbers

analytic.title: Multiple-Attribute Decision-Making based on Archimedean Bonferroni Operators of q-Rung Orthopair Fuzzy Numbers

biblStruct.note: This article has been accepted for publication in a future issue of this journal, but has not been fully edited. Content may change prior to final publication. Citation information: DOI 10.1109/TFUZZ.2018.2826452, IEEE Transactions on Fuzzy Systems

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: The theory of q-rung orthopair fuzzy sets (q-ROFSs) proposed by Yager can more effectively describe fuzzy information in the real-world. Because q-ROFSs contain a parameter q and can adjust the range of expressed fuzzy information, they are more superior to intuitionistic fuzzy sets (IFSs) and Pythagorean fuzzy sets (PFSs). Archimedean T-norm and T-conorm (ATT) is an important tool to generate operational rules, so many general operational rules can be provided by ATT based on the q-rung orthopair fuzzy numbers (q-ROFNs). Meanwhile, the Bonferroni mean (BM) operator has the prominent advantage that it can consider the interrelationships between the different attributes. Therefore, it is an important and meaningful innovation to extend the BM operator to the q-ROFNs based on the ATT. In this paper, we firstly discuss and give some q-rung orthopair fuzzy operational rules by using ATT. Further we extend BM operator to the q-ROFNs, and propose the q-Rung Orthopair fuzzy Archimedean BM (q-ROFABM) operator and the q-Rung Orthopair fuzzy weighted Archimedean BM (q-ROFWABM) operator and study their desirable properties. Then, a new multiple-attribute decision-making (MADM) method is developed based on q-ROFWABM operator. Finally, we use the practical example to verify its effectiveness and superiority by comparing with other existing methods.
Index Terms-q-Rung Orthopair fuzzy sets; Archimedean T-norm and T-conorm; Bonferroni mean; Multi-attribute decision-making.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: ultiple-attribute decision-making (MADM) is a process that it can give the ranking results for the finite alternatives according to the attribute values of different alternatives. In recent years, some hot decision problems, such as the strategic choice of enterprises and the behavior of government procurement, are all related to the MADM. In real decision process, the first question is how to effectively and accurately express the attribute value of uncertain decision information. Because of the complexity of human cognition and decision-making environment, exact values are not enough to express fuzzy information. Therefore, many fuzzy information expression tools came into being [6,15,19]. The IFS, firstly presented by Atanassov [1,2], is improved from fuzzy sets (FSs) by Zadeh [45], and it has a membership degree (MD), a non-membership degree (NMD) and a hesitancy degree (HD), which can express the degree of satisfaction, the degree of dissatisfaction and the degree of hesitancy, respectively. IFS is a very valuable tool, so it is widely applied to describe fuzzy decision information and studied by a large Manuscript received XXX.

number of experts and scholars. These researches mainly include the following aspects: (1) the basic theory research, such as operational laws of intuitionistic fuzzy numbers (IFNs) [8], distance measures between IFNs [7], [34], similarity measures between IFNs [5], information entropy of IFNs [14],…, etc. (2) Some extended MADM methods for IFNs, such as the application of government E-Tendering based on the TOPSIS methods [36], the application of optimizing multi-response problems in IFS based on VIKOR method [29], the supplier selection of a supply chain based on ELECTRE-III method [27], the distributor evaluation and selection problem based on TODIM method [20], and so on. (3) The intuitionistic fuzzy aggregation operators, for example, Xu [39] and Xu and Yager [40] presented some basic weighted averaging (WA) operator and the weighted geometric (WG) operator for IFNs, respectively. Liu [22] and Zhang et al. [46] presented some extended aggregation operators based on the special Hamacher operation rules and Frank operation rules, respectively, and they are more superior by using a flexible parameter. Xu and Yager [41] proposed the BM operator whose prominent features is that the interrelationships between different attributes can be take into account,…, etc.

However, the application range of IFSs is narrow because it has a condition that the sum of MD u and NMD v is equal to or less than 1, i.e., 1 uv . In this case, some decision evaluation values cannot be effectively expressed by IFSs because some decision makers may give some data that the sum of MD and NMD is greater than 1. For example, a decision maker give the MD is 0.8 and NMD is 0.6. It is obvious that the IFNs cannot express this result. Therefore, in order to solve this problem, Yager [42] proposed a new concept of the Pythagorean fuzzy set (PFS), which eminent characteristic is that the square sum of MD and NMD is less than or equal to 1 i.e., 22 1 uv  . So, the PFS can describe a lot of fuzzy information that the IFS cannot describe in some practical problems. Based on this theory, some extensive researches have been carried out. For example, Yager and Abbasov [44] studied the relationship between the Pythagorean fuzzy numbers (PFNs) and the complex numbers. Yager [42] proposed some new Pythagorean fuzzy weighted average operator and Pythagorean fuzzy geometric-aggregated operator. Peng and Yang [30] presented some new operations such as division, subtraction based on PFNs, and proposed a Pythagorean fuzzy superiority and inferiority ranking method. Zhang and Xu [48] defined the distance measure based on PFNs and presented an extension of TOPSIS method for solving MADM problems. Ren et al. [32] presented the Pythagorean fuzzy TODIM approach to deal with the MADM problems. Garg [12,13] proposed some new Pythagorean fuzzy generalized aggregation operators by combining Einstein operations and studied their some desirable properties. Zhang [47] presented a new closeness index-based ranking method based on PFNs to manage heterogeneous information, …, etc.

With the development of theory, a new concept was presented 2 again by Yager [43], the q-rung orthopair fuzzy set (q-ROFS), in which the sum of the q th power of MD and the q th power of NMD is restricted to one i.e., 1 qq uv  . We can find that the q-ROFS is more general, because IFS and PFS are all its special cases (when q = 1 and q = 2). It is worth noting that as the rung q increases, the space of acceptable orthopairs increases, the more orthopairs satisfy the bounding constraint. So we can express a wider range of fuzzy information by using q-ROFSs.

In other word, we can dynamically adjust the value of the parameter q to determine the information expression range. For example, we can increase the value of q when the ambiguity of decision information increases. In reality, some experts may be jointly affected by personal wishes and the surrounding environment. So, they can evaluate a certain decision-making thing in vague or contradictory condition, and the evaluation results from these experts maybe have a MD of 0.7 and a NMD of 0.8. In this case, both IFNs and PFNs are unusable, but the q-ROFNs can describe these fuzzy information by increasing the value of parameter q. Thus the q-ROFS is more flexible and more suitable for describing the uncertain information. To understand their differences more intuitively, a comparison of the space range of IFNs, PFNs and q-ROFNs is shown in Fig. 1.
Fig. 1. A comparison of the space ranges of IFNs, PFNs and q-ROFNs.

For solving the MADM problems, we usually have two ways. One is the traditional methods such as TOPSIS, VIKOR, ELECTRE, and so on. The other is the aggregation operators (AOs). AOs can more effectively to solve the problems of information integration than the traditional approaches. Because AOs can provide the comprehensive values of the alternatives and then give the ranking results, whereas traditional approaches can only give the ranking results. Recently, many experts and scholars have begun to study the information integration, so a lot of articles about AOs have appeared in MADM fields. In general, we consider AOs from two aspects: the operational rules and the functions. (1) For the operational rules, some AOs are from the algebraic operational laws that they are the special and important members in the T-norm (TN) and T-conorm (TC) family. Generally, the Archimedean T-norm and T-conorm (ATT) are the generalization of a lot of TNs and TCs, many operational rules based on the special cases of ATT were developed, such as Einstein operational rules [24], Hamacher operational rules [22], Frank operational rules [46], Dombi operational rules [25], and so on. Then some aggregation operators are proposed, for example, some extended intuitionistic fuzzy AOs [3,23,38] based on the ATT were proposed, they provide general expressions for AOs. (2) For the functions, the traditional AOs [39,40] only can aggregate multiple numbers into one number. So some extended and versatile AOs have been presented in the last few years. For example, Zhang et al. [46] presented some new power aggregation (PA) operators of IFNs which can take advantage of the attribute values to support for each other and eliminate the influence of extreme value from the bias of decision makers. Wang et al. [35] proposed some dependent AOs for IFNs, they can relieve the impact of unreasonable data by using the dependent weights. Xu and Yager [41] proposed BM operators for IFNs whose function is that can consider the interrelationships between different attributes.

In real decision-making environment, the interrelationships between attributes are common. For example, when we evaluate the quality of a mobile phone, its performance and mobile phone hardware configuration are related. So, it is important and useful to consider the interrelationships between different attributes when we make a more reasonable decision. Moreover, because of the complexity of decision problems, it's necessary to build some general and versatile AOs based on ATT for q-ROFNs. At the same time, q-ROFNs can express uncertain information in the wider range. Based on the above analysis, we can see that (1) The q-ROFNs are much better than IFNs and PFNs to describe the fuzzy information, their expressions are more flexible and broader for solving MADM problems. (2) The ATT is an important tool that can generate the general and versatile operational rules for IFNs and the AOs based on the ATT are more flexible and more versatile for aggregating fuzzy information. However, so far, these TNs and TCs have not been applied to q-ROFNs. (3) The BM operator has a significant advantage that can consider the interrelationships between different attributes, but it is only generated from Algebraic operational rules and applied in IFS, and it doesn't have the generality and flexibility for solving MADM problems, because it doesn't adopt the general ATT. Based on the above comprehensive analysis, it is important and useful to extend the BM operator to q-ROFNs based on the ATT and apply them to solve MADM problems. So, we combine the BM operator with q-ROFNs based on the ATT and present some new q-Rung Orthopair fuzzy Archimedean BM operators and develop a new MADM method under the q-Rung Orthopair fuzzy environment to deal with more complex MADM problems in this paper. It is worth noting that the proposed AOs and method have these advantages: (1) The scope of expressing vague information is wider and more flexible. (2) They are more general by using the ATT. (3) They can consider the interrelationships between different attributes.

We can arrange our article through the following structure. In Section 2, we mainly introduce fundamental concepts of q-ROFSs, ATT and BM operator. In Section 3, we present the q-Rung Orthopair fuzzy Archimedean BM (q-ROFABM) operator and the q-Rung Orthopair fuzzy weighted Archimedean BM (q-ROFWABM) operator and study some of their characteristics. In Section 4, we present a new MADM method by using the proposed q-ROFWABM operator and give detailed steps. In Section 5, we use the practical application example to prove the effectiveness of the presented MADM method and compare it with the existing methods. In Section 6, we have the conclusions of this paper.

div.head: II. PRELIMINARIES
div.p: In order to better understand the paper, we will introduce some basic and useful concepts of q-ROFSs [43], ATT and BM operator [41] in this section.

div.head: D. The BM operator
div.p: BM was first proposed by Bonferroni [4], it has the function that can capture the interrelationships between different integrated numbers. It can be defined as follows:
div.formula: Definition 2.6 [4] [41]. Suppose ( 1, 2, , ) k a k m  L

div.head: III. THE q-RUNG ORTHOPAIR FUZZY BONFERRONI MEAN OPERATORS BASED ON THE ATT
div.p: In this section, we propose the q-Rung Orthopair fuzzy Archimedean BM (q-ROFABM) operator and the q-Rung Orthopair fuzzy weighted Archimedean BM (q-ROFWABM) operator by using the operational rules of the ATT of q-ROFNs. The properties of these new operators will be proved and their some special cases will be discussed.

div.head: B. The q-Rung Orthopair fuzzy weighted Archimedean BM operator

About the specific expressions of u and v  , please see Appendix IX.

div.head: A NEW MADM METHOD BASED ON THE PROPOSED Q-ROFWABM OPERATOR
div.p: In the section, we will present a new MADM method from the proposed q-ROFWABM operator to solve MADM problems based on q-ROFNs. The . Then based on the proposed q-ROFWABM operator, we give a novel MADM method by considering interrelationships between different attributes. The proposed MADM method is presented as follows:

div.head: V. THE PRACTICAL APPLICATION EXAMPLES
div.p: In this section, we use the practical examples to analyze the results of the new proposed method and we prove the effectiveness and superiority of new method by comparing it with other existing different methods.

div.head: A. The application of the proposed method
div.p: In the following, we use a practical example to demonstrate how the new proposed method is to solve MADM problems. Suppose there are five companies A1, A2, A3, A4, A5 which are evaluated for investment based on the three attributes: the business growth ability 1 () C , the enterprise management level presented by q-ROFN
div.formula: , ij ij ij Q u v 
div.p: , where the Hamacher TN and TC were adopted, then the decision matrix ij QQ    (i = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5; j = 1, 2, 3) is constructed and shown in Table III. We let the parameters
 and 1.5   . The goal of this MADM problem is to select the best company for investing.
The proposed method to deal with the MADM problem is shown as follows:
Step 1: Normalizing the decision-making information. Because three attribute values are all the benefit type, we don't need to standardize the decision matrix Q in this step, i.e., QQ  % .
Step 2: Apply the proposed q-ROFWABM operator shown in Eq. ( 55) to get the overall preference values i Q % of each alternative Ai (i = 1, 2,L , m), shown as follows: Step 4: Because
% , we can get the ranking result: 5

div.p: Therefore, the best alternative is 5 A .
Step 5: End.

div.head: B. An analysis of the special cases and the influence of the parameter values on the MADM results
div.p: In the following, we analysis the experimental result from different special cases based on the different operations of ATTs. The ranking results are shown in Table IV

div.p: *Note: For convenience, we simplify the SV of i Q % to i S , for example, 11 () S S Q  % . In the following content, all SVs are expressed in this way.

In the following, in order to illustrate the influence of different values of the parameters ,, q s t and  on the ranking results of the alternatives, we adjust different parameter values in Step 2 of the proposed MADM method to rank the alternatives. It is worth noting that when parameter 1   and 2   , the Hamacher operations can reduce to the Algebraic operations and the Einstein operations, respectively. So, for the sake of simplicity, we only use Hamacher operations to stand for the ATT family, i.e., we adopt q-ROFWHBM operator to analysis the influence of different parameter values (we set
). The ranking results of the alternatives for different values of the parameter q are shown in Table V.

div.p: From Table V, we find that the ranking results with the different parameter q are different. When q = 1or 2, the ranking results are " 5 2 4 3 1

div.p: So, the best alternatives of the ranking results are changed as the parameter q changes. It is obvious that if the parameter q = 1, then q-ROFNs become IFNs; if the parameter q = 2, then q-ROFNs become PFNs. About how to obtain a reasonable value of the parameter q, it should be based on the evaluating values given by the experts and it can take the smallest integer q satisfying the inequality 1 qq uv  . For example, if the evaluating value given by the expert is <0.8, 0.7>, then we can set the value of the parameter q to 3 due to the fact that 22 0.8 0.7 1
 , where the smallest integer q is 3.

In the following, we analyze the influence of the parameter  from Hamacher operations, the ranking results are shown in Table VI VI, we find that the values of the SVs become greater and greater as the value of parameter  increases. But the ranking results are all same, the best choices are all 5
div.formula: (we set 1, 1, 1 q s t    ). From Table
div.p: A . The parameter  can be viewed as the "decision maker's attitude". The greater the value of parameter  is, the more optimistic attitude the decision makers have, and vice versa. So the different decision makers can choose the appropriate  based on their attitude. For example, when the decision maker is an optimist, he/she can choose a large  value.

div.p: Then, we analyze the influences of the parameters s and t based on the q-ROFWHBM operator, we can get the following ranking results in Table VII (we set 1, 1.5 q   ). For Table VII, we can find that the best choices are same for different parameters s and t , although the ranking results are different. This is because the q-ROFWHBM operator can take into account the interrelationships between different attributes, so we can have the different ranking results by setting different parameter values s and t . When one of the two arguments takes zero, it means that the q-ROFWHBM operator cannot consider the interrelationships between attributes. Usually, in practical applications, for easy calculation, we can take some simple integer values for parameters s and t , for example, when 1 st , we take into account the interrelationships between different attributes, and when 0 s  or 0 t  , we do not take into account the interrelationships between different attributes.

div.head: C. The comparative analysis with the existing methods (1) The verification of the effectiveness
div.p: In order to verity the effectiveness of the developed method, we use three existing MADM methods to deal with the above example and make a comparative analysis. The three existing MADM methods based on three different aggregation operators: the intuitionistic fuzzy weighted averaging (ATS-IFWA) operator based on the ATT proposed by Xia et al. [38], the Pythagorean fuzzy Einstein weighted averaging (PFEWA) operator by Garg [12], the weighted intuitionistic fuzzy BM (WIFBM) operator proposed by Xu and Yager [41].

In order to have a general representation and simplify the calculation, we adopted the Hamacher intuitionistic fuzzy weighted averaging (HIFWA) operator to stand for the ATS-IFWA operator, and used the q-ROFWHBM operator to stand for q-ROFWABM operator. Where we set [38] and Xu and Yager's method [41] are same. Although the ranking result from Garg's method [12] (2) Further comparative analysis In the previous section, we have shown the effectiveness of the proposed method. But, because the ranking results from these methods are almost the same, it cannot reflect the advantages of our method very well. So, in this sub-section, we do a comparative analysis by constantly adjusting some data in the above example. Because 5
A is the best alternative, we can adjust the evaluation value of alternative 5

A . For example, we can adjust the data 53 Q % from 0.6,0.3 to 0.01,0.89 by keeping MD getting smaller and smaller, NMD getting bigger and bigger. Obviously, the reduction of attribute value 53 Q % will affect the ranking result of alternative 5 A , and it may turn from the best to the bad one.

To reflect the characteristic of the proposed method clearly, we compare it with the method from Xia et al. [38] for this experiment, where the method from Xia et al. [38] is based on the HIFWA operator. Obviously, the proposed method can take into account the interrelationships between different attributes, and the Xia et al.' method does not take into account the interrelationships between different attributes. The experimental results from these two methods are listed in Table IX , and  from [38]).

For Table IX, we find that the SVs of alternative 5 A from the two methods are all becoming smaller and smaller with the decrease of evaluation value 53 Q % . the SV from the proposed method decreases faster than that produced from Xia et al.'s method. When the attribute value 53 Q % is reduced from 0.6,0.3 to 0.01,0.89 , the SV of alternative 5
A from Xia et al.'s method is decrease from 0.4557 to 0.2434 and the SV of alternative 5

A from the proposed method is decrease from 0.4331 0.0584. Obviously, the SV from Xia et al.'s method decreases more slowly than that produced from the proposed method. This reason may be that the proposed method considers the interrelationships between the attributes while Xia et al.'s method does not, which is the only difference between the two methods.

From Table X, we can find that: (1) When the attribute value 53 Q % is reduced from 0.6,0.3 to 0.4,0.5 , the ranking result of alternative 5 A from the proposed method has been changed and its ranking position drops from first to second, whereas the ranking result from Xia et al.'s method has not been changed and its ranking position is still the first; (2) When the attribute value 53 Q % is reduced from 0.2,0.7 to 0.01,0.89 , the ranking result of alternative 5

A from the proposed method has also been changed and its ranking position drops from third to fifth, whereas the ranking result from Xia et al.'s method has not been changed and its ranking position is the third.
div.formula: A A A A A f f f f 5 2 4 3 1 A A A A A f f f f 0.4, 0.5 2 5 4 3 1 A A A A A f f f f 5 2 4 3 1 A A A A A f f f f 0.2, 0.7 2 4 5 3 1 A A A A A f f f f 2 4 5 3 1 A A A A A f f f f 0.01, 0.89 2 4 3 1 5 A A A A A f f f f 2 4 5 3 1 A A A A A f f f f
div.p: For the above results, we can explain as follows. According to common sense, when the evaluation value decreases, the corresponding scoring value of alternative will be reduced, so its ranking position will be changed, it is likely to become more and more backward. On the other hand, because the evaluation values of the other alternatives are not changed, their order relationships are not changed too. In this experiment, we can find this conclusion from the Table XI, i.e., the optimal alternative is changed from 5

A to 2 A when the evaluation value 53 Q % is reduced to 0.4,0.5 by the proposed method or is reduced to 0. A A A A A f f f f . Obviously, this is because the proposed method can take into account the interrelationships between different attributes. So the ranking results obtained from the proposed method are more reasonable. In other words, the proposed method is superior and more effective than Xia et al.'s method by considering the interrelationship of attributes in solving practical decision-making problems.

In addition, in the practical MADM problems, IFNs have a disadvantage that the summation of the MD and the NMD need to be less than or equal to 1, i.e., 1 uv . Therefore, IFNs 12 cannot be used to fully describe evaluating attribute values. In order to consider this situation, we replace the evaluating value 21 Q % = 0.5,0.2 in the decision matrix Q % shown in Table III In Table XI, we find that the ranking result of Garg's method [12] is the same as the result from the proposed method. For the Xia et al.'s method [38] and Xu and Yager's [41], because their scope of application is very they can only deal with the decision-making problems expressed by IFNs, however, IFNs cannot fully express the real decision information because its MD and NMD must meet 01 uv    . And the PFN of the Garg's method is more superior than the IFN, because it requires MD and NMD can conform to 22 01 uv    , it can express the attribute value more completely. But, the Garg's method also has some limitations. For example, we replace the evaluating value 21 Q % with the evaluating value 0.9,0.4 , it cannot deal with this data and get the ranking result. For the proposed method in this paper, it is the most superior way to express the fuzzy decision information by the q-ROFNs with a flexible parameter q. By increasing the value of parameter q, the scope of the expressed decision-making information will be wider, thus they can avoid the distortion of information. So the proposed method is more suitable for practical decision-making problems.

(3) Summary about the advantages of the proposed method compared with the existing methods (a) Comparing with Xia et al.'s method [38] based on the ATS-IFWA operator 1) On the aspect of information expression, Xia et al.'s method is based on IFNs, and the proposed method is based on q-ROFNs. IFNs cannot fully express the real decision information because its MD and NMD must meet 01 uv    . But the q-ROFNs are more superior than the IFNs, because they require MD and NMD must conform to 01 qq uv    , so they can express the attribute value more widely and more flexibly by a parameter q. By increasing the value of parameter q, the scope of the expressed decision-making information will be wider, thus they can avoid the distortion of information. So the method proposed in this paper is more suitable for practical decision-making problems.

2) On the aspect of operational rules, it is easy to see that the two methods are all based on the ATT. The ATT is similar to a generator that can provide the generalized operational rules in respect to IFNs. Its special cases, for example, have Algebraic operational rules, Einstein operational rules, Hamacher operational rules and Frank operational rules, and so on. So we extended them to the q-ROFNs and proposed the q-ROFWABM operator with universality and variability. 3) On the aspect of the AOs, the ATS-IFWA operator adopted simple arithmetic weighting function which does not take into account interrelationships of different attributes and the proposed q-ROFWABM operator used the BM aggregation operator which can consider interrelationships of different attributes. In practical applications, there are the interrelationships between different attributes in MADM problems. So the proposed method based on the q-ROFWABM operator can more effectively solve the actual MADM problems. (b) Comparing with Garg's method [12] based on the Pythagorean fuzzy Einstein weighted averaging (PFEWA) operator 1) On the aspect of information expression, Garg's method is based on the PFNs. PFNs are more superior than the IFNs, because they require MD and NMD must conform to 22 01 uv    , they can express the attribute value more completely. But the range of information expressed by PFNs is still limited, for example, the evaluating value 0.8,0.7 , it cannot be expressed by the PFNs. In this case, we need to use the q-ROFNs to describe the fuzzy information completely. So, the proposed method is more superior and more applicable to realistic decision problems.

2) On the operational rules, the proposed method used the ATT, whereas Garg's method is based on the Einstein operations. The Einstein operations are only the special cases of the ATT family, so the proposed method is more general and more diverse than Garg's method. For example, the q-ROFWABM operator from the proposed method can reduce into corresponding Hamacher operator and Frank operator, they are more flexible and practical by the different ATTs. So the q-ROFWABM operator has the generalization. 3) On the aspect of the AOs, the proposed method uses the BM operator which can consider interrelationship of attributes, whereas the PFEWA operator only adopted simple arithmetic weighting function which does not consider interrelationship of attributes. So in the real application environment, the proposed method is more applicable. [41] based on the weighted intuitionistic fuzzy BM (WIFBM) operator 1) On the aspect of information expression, Xu and Yager's method is based on the IFNs which their ability to express fuzzy information is limited. However, the proposed method can solve this drawback by using the q-ROFNs. We can express any fuzzy number by adjusting the variable parameter q. This function is flexible and important in practical applications. 2) On the operational rules, Xu and Yager's method only used the most common Algebraic operational rules which are a special case of ATT family. Although it is simple in calculation, it is difficult to solve the complex decision problem in reality. The proposed method used the general ATT, it is more in line with people's cognition about complex decision-making problems. In addition, the proposed method can reflect the decision maker's attitude by a flexible parameter based on some special cases, such as Hamacher operational rules. 3) On the aspect of the AOs, the proposed method and Xu and Yager's method all use the BM operator which can consider interrelationships of different attributes. In the practical MADM problems, many attributes are related, so we must consider the correlation among attributes in order to get more real and reliable integration results.

A comprehensive comparison for these methods is shown in Table XII. According to the comparisons and analysis above, the method based on the q-ROFWABM operator proposed in this paper is better than the existing other methods for aggregating the fuzzy information. Therefore, it is more suitable to solve the problems of MADM.

div.head: VI. CONCLUSIONS
div.p: The IFS and PFS are a good tool to the express the fuzzy information. However, q-ROFS is more general, its outstanding feature is that it has a parameter q which can express the information more flexibly and can describe a wider range of fuzzy information. In order to better integrate fuzzy information, we have applied the BM operator to the q-Rung Orthopair fuzzy environment based on ATT. Then we have developed the q-Rung Orthopair fuzzy Archimedean BM (q-ROFABM) operator and q-Rung Orthopair fuzzy weighted Archimedean BM (q-ROFWABM) operator, and have studied their some properties. Furthermore, we have presented a new method based on q-ROFWABM operator to solve the MADM problems. Finally, we have used the practical cases to illustrate the feasibility and superiority of the proposed method by comparative analysis with the other existing methods.

In further research, considering the superiority of new q-ROFS, we can study some of their fuzzy preference relations [28,37], we can also extend them to other some decision methods, such as TOPSIS methods, VIKOR method, ELECTRE method and TODIM method, and so on, and apply them to deal with some practical decision-making problems, such as group decision making [49], fuzzy cluster analysis [21], emotion recognition [16], budget allocation [17] and consensus model [31], etc. Further, we will also explore the feasibility about whether q-rung orthopair Fuzzy sets u q + v q ≤ 1 can be extended to rq-rung quasi-orthopair fuzzy sets u q + v r ≤ 1, including their meaning in decision making, operational rules, comparison method, and so on.
